title-group.article-title: Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction appearing in remote period of right ventricular septal pacing in patient with left ventricular septal bulge

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Cardiology, National Hospital Organisation Kagoshima Medical Center, Kagoshima, Japan

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: A woman in her 70 s presented with fatigue and dyspnoea during exertion. Six years ago, she had been implanted with a dual chamber pacemaker with the lead placement at the high septal site of the right ventricle. Echocardiography demonstrated the presence of the previously detected left ventricular septal bulge along with a newly observed systolic turbulent mosaic at left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) and a systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve. Electrophysiological pacing study and simultaneously performed echocardiography demonstrated that the apical pacing decreases the pressure gradient at the left ventricular outflow tract LVOT. We changed the lead position of the pacemaker from the high septal to the apical site of the right ventricle. During the follow-up period, recurrence of the obstruction at the LVOT with SAM was not detected. In the case with septal bulge, it is necessary to choose the apical position as the pacemaker lead placement.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: It is reported that conventional apical pacing causes electrical and mechanical dyssynchrony, which may lead to potential harm such as negative remodelling and worsening heart failure.1 Therefore, in our institution, we have been actively choosing the high interventricular septum, left bundle branch area and His bundle area as the placement site of the ventricular lead. In such circumstances, we experienced a rare case of a patient with septal bulge who presented with symptoms and haemodynamicss resembling hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) in the remote period after pacemaker implantation.

sec.title: Case presentation
sec.p: A woman in her 70 s had a pacemaker implanted with the diagnosis of complete atrioventricular block (figure 1). At that time, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a left ventricular septal bulge, but neither findings of increased pressure gradient at the site of the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) nor systolic anterior motion (SAM) were observed. The Valsalva stress test showed no increase in pressure gradient and no specific pharmacologic therapy was initiated post-implantation. However, after 6 years, she was presented with fatigue and dyspnoea during walking and farming her garden that had been exacerbated for the past week. A 12-lead ECG showed a pacemaker rhythm with a QRS duration of 148 msec. The chest radiograph showed no pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly or pleural effusion. TTE revealed an ejection fraction of 68%. Under the Valsalva manoeuvre, the obstruction at LVOT with 116 mmHg gradient and SAM was evoked (figure 2). Oral administration of cibenzoline of 300 mg and metoprolol of 2.5 mg daily was attempted to improve HOCM-like symptoms and haemodynamics, but it proved entirely ineffective. We hypothesised a link between the pacemaker lead position and this HOCM-like haemodynamics.

caption.title: Chest X-ray front view after initial pacemaker implantation.
Echocardiograms. Left ventricular outflow tract blood flow and systolic anterior motion of mitral valve.

sec.title: Investigations
sec.p: An electrophysiological pacing study was performed with simultaneous catheter-based haemodynamical investigation to examine the relation of pacing site and the pressure gradient between the aortic root and the left ventricle. Under non-pharmacological conditions, we could not find out a significant pressure gradient with either apical or high septal pacing. However, under the provocation using isoproterenol, the pressure gradient of 48 mmHg was observed during the high septal pacing, but not apical pacing (figure 3). We could haemodynamically verify that pacing at the high septal site caused the obstruction of the LVOT in this patient.

caption.title: Cardiac catheterisation. (left) A fluoroscopy image in right anterior oblique projection during catheter-based haemodynamic testing. (right) ECG and pressure gradient between the left ventricle outflow tract and aorta during right ventricular septal pacing apex pacing.

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: We initially attempted to remove the lead previously placed at the high septal site, but were unable to do so due to the adhesion around the superior vena cava. The lead was reluctantly left in place as a non-functional one. We finally changed the pacing site from the high septal to the apical site by adding a new lead insertion and placement (figure 4).

caption.title: Chest X-ray front view after addition of right ventricular apex lead.

sec.title: Outcome and follow-up
sec.p: Postoperative echocardiographic evaluation revealed resolution of the obstruction at the LVOT and SAM. The symptoms of fatigue and dyspnoea on exertion also improved. During the subsequent 9-year follow-up period, no recurrence of the obstruction at the LVOT and SAM was detected on serial echocardiographies.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: According to the 2023 European Society of Cardiology guideline for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, dual chamber pacing is recommended as a Class IIb intervention for patients with LVOT obstruction who are contraindicated for septal reduction therapy or have a high likelihood of developing atrioventricular conduction disturbances as a result of septal reduction therapy.2

The debate over whether septal or apical pacing is superior has persisted without reaching a definitive conclusion.35 Recently, conduction system pacing methods such as His-bundle pacing and left bundle area pacing have garnered attention as physiological pacing options.68 Gadler et al reported on the impact of pacing sites at LVOT in 15 patients with HOCM.9 Their report indicated that the high septal pacing did not alleviate LVOT obstruction, whereas apical pacing improved it.

In this present case, although either HCM or HOCM was not initially diagnosed, the basal ventricular septal hypertrophy was locally observed at the time of the pacemaker implantation. The Valsalva stress test showed no increase in pressure gradient. At the result, we implanted a pacemaker with the choice of the high septal site as the placement of the ventricular pacing lead. This long-term high septal pacing may have had a negative impact on the manner of the left ventricular motion and the remodelling process.

In other words, in addition to the pre-existing septal bulge, long-term high septal pacing caused hypercontraction of the basal region of the left ventricular septum, evoking the obstruction and increased pressure gradients at the LVOT. This resulted in the Venturi effect or a lifting force due to abnormal blood flow from the posterior and lateral wall to the LVOT, which eventually induced SAM. However, alternative mechanisms include hypertension-induced hypertrophy of the basal septum (sigmoid septum) and progressive aortic elongation increasing the angulation between the aortic root and LVOT, promoting septal encroachment into the outflow tract. Both may have contributed to the observed obstruction.
We used isoproterenol to demonstrate the left ventricular outflow tract pressure gradient. Although isoproterenol is considered less physiological, its use here enabled dynamic assessment.

Ultimately, these vicious haemodynamical abnormalities were corrected by changing the pacing site from the high septal to the apical site. The paradoxical septal motion induced by apical pacing probably alleviated the basal septal wall hypercontraction, the LVOT obstruction and SAM. While apical pacing can lead to slight decreases in LVEF, our patient maintained preserved systolic function throughout the follow-up.
Our findings are consistent with randomised trials of DDD pacing in HOCM, which demonstrated gradient reduction and symptomatic improvement.10

Recent therapies such as cardiac myosin inhibitors have shown promise in reducing LVOT gradients by decreasing contractility.11 12 Alcohol septal ablation has also shown excellent outcomes in patients with sigmoid septum and LVOT obstruction.13

As mentioned above, the occurrence of LVOT obstruction and SAM during conduction system pacing like high septal pacing in non-HCM patients with only a local septal bulge, and the subsequent improvement of those vicious haemodynamical phenomena with a shift to the apical pacing, is extremely rare. Further intricate investigation of the haemodynamic mechanisms in such cases is needed.

list-item.p: In patients with left ventricular septal bulge, the high ventricular septal pacing may potentially result in exacerbation or development of left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Careful consideration is required for the selection of placement site of the pacing lead in patients with left ventricular septal bulge.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

Case reports provide a valuable learning resource for the scientific community and can indicate areas of interest for future research. They should not be used in isolation to guide treatment choices or public health policy.
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Consent obtained directly from patient(s).
